conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the small ball.
Identify the gravitational force \( \vec{F}_g = m \vec{g} \) acting vertically downward.
Identify the tension \( \vec{T} \) in the string acting along the string.
Identify the electric force \( \vec{F}_e = q \vec{E} \) acting horizontally due to the uniform electric field.
Since the ball is in equilibrium, the vector sum of the forces must be zero.
Break down the forces into their horizontal and vertical components.
The gravitational force has only a vertical component: \( F_{g,y} = mg \).
The electric force has only a horizontal component: \( F_{e,x} = qE \).
The tension in the string has both horizontal and vertical components.
The vertical component of the tension must balance the gravitational force, and the horizontal component must balance the electric force.
The vertical component of the tension is \( T \cos \theta \) and the horizontal component is \( T \sin \theta \).
Write the vertical equilibrium condition: \( T \cos \theta = mg \).
Write the horizontal equilibrium condition: \( T \sin \theta = qE \).
Solve for the tension \( T \) from the vertical equilibrium: \( T = \frac{mg}{\cos \theta} \).
Substitute the expression for \( T \) into the horizontal equilibrium equation: \( \left( \frac{mg}{\cos \theta} \right) \sin \theta = qE \).
Simplify the left-hand side to get \( mg \tan \theta = qE \).
Solve for the electric field \( E \): \( E = \frac{mg \tan \theta}{q} \).
Determine the electric field strength as \( \boxed{\frac{mg \tan \theta}{q}} \).
